utterances: Just two weeks before her - before the primary, one of her long-time supporters, a former staffer, now a political blogger said he'd had an affair with her.
And then about five days later, a political lobbyist said, I had a one-night stand with Nikki Haley.
And to both allegations, Nikki Haley said, no, I've been 100 percent faithful to my husband of 13 years.
And in fact, the allegations so far unproven, seem only to have solidified her voter base.
And she really brought out a lot of people to yesterday's - almost a record number of voters in this Republican primary yesterday.
We're talking with Julie Rose, a reporter for our member station WFAE in Charlotte.
You're listening to the Political Junkie segment on TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Ken?
Julie, I heard a lot of Republican officials, first of all, very excited about Nikki Haley's showing yesterday.
She got 49 percent of the vote.
She barely missed winning the nomination outright.
And they basically talked about her as if she was the nominee.
How much pressure is there on Congressman Barrett to drop out of the runoff?
There's a quite a bit of pressure, although, so far - I mean, in the last 24 hours, he has given no indication that he plans to drop out.
He did only get 22 percent of the vote to Haley's 49 percent.
And in South Carolina, it's also important to remember that only people who voted in the first primary can vote in the second primary, the runoff.
So Haley - Nikki Haley definitely has the deck stacked, if you will, coming into this June 22nd primary.
And let's get Denise(ph) on the line, Denise with us from Columbia, South Carolina.
Yes, Neal.
I just wanted to say that don't crown Nikki Haley the governor yet because the minority faction of South Carolina has not spoken yet.
And we plan to galvanize our support for our candidate.
I think, overall, the state is tired of the Republicans, regardless of whether it's Nikki Haley or Barrett or anybody.
But we need to move forward in a totally different direction, and I think we got a real shot at it.
Julie Rose, do the polls support that?
She makes a good point, your caller does.
The Democrat running for - that will face whoever comes out of this runoff between Haley and Barrett is Vincent Sheheen.
And he has run a very solid campaign, overcoming a state - as a state superintendent of public schools, actually, a statewide officeholder there.
And he is unknown.
He has less baggage, less connections to the establishment.
And so, there definitely is a sentiment according to the polls in the South Carolina that people are tired, first of all, of having their lawmakers' sex lives dragged through late night jokes and...
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
Yeah.

And they're eager to see a change and to kind of - and one thing that Vincent Sheheen, the Democrat, has been talking about is, you know, look, we've seen what we've been through with Governor Sanford in office for the last year.
Do we want another Republican who also potentially has sex scandals attached him or her?
Let's move on.
I'm your guy, so...
Denise, thanks for the call.
Appreciate it.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Ken?
And Julie, plus the fact that - basically, the Sanford political machine seems to have united behind Haley.
And Mark Sanford, I think, vouched for her integrity.
It's like, you know, Ken Rudin vouching for Neal Conan's integrity, you know, wears it as a badge of honor.
With friends like that, yeah.
There was a lot of concern early on.
I mean, Governor Sanford endorsed Nikki Haley as his chosen heir just right before, I think, the whole Argentinean affair, hike down the Appalachian Trail thing happened last summer.
And so a lot of people thought, oh, you know, Nikki Haley is done for because she's got the Sanford stamp, it's going to, you know, ruin any chance that she has of success.
And that certainly has not been the case.
We'll be checking back in with you.
Julie Rose, thanks very much for your time.
You're welcome.
Thank you.
Julie Rose, a reporter for member station WFAE in Charlotte.
Ken, this email question: What do the overall results of the primaries to date suggest about the outcome of the November elections?
Will the Democrats retain control of the House and Senate?
Well, I think everybody feels yes.
The question is how much, how close the Republicans will get.
They need 10 seats in the Senate to take control, and that probably includes Joe Lieberman switching and all that stuff.
But, no, they will - Republicans - Democrats will maintain control.
Republicans still look like they will gain in the House and Senate.
All right.
That email - I forgot to mention - from Charles(ph) in Birmingham, Alabama.
Ken Rudin, as always, we thank you very much for your time.
And thanks, mom, for coming in.
And thanks to her - his mom, Claire, for reading the trivia question for us this week.
Coming up, some critics complain that President Obama isn't mad enough about the oil spill.
Are we seeing a tougher-talking president?
Do you want a tougher-talking president?
And I'm Michele Norris.
Yeah, totally.
I mean, the house just next door to hers was flooded.
The guy living there said the water ruined his computers, business papers.
He lost a lot.
Those floodwaters missed Angie's house, I am serious, by just a matter of inches.
It's Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
Neal Conan is away.
I'm Guy Raz.
By the time Jennifer Traig graduated high school, she'd convinced herself she had, among other diseases, skin cancer, meningitis and pancreatitis.
The odd headache meant a brain tumor, leg cramps meant Parkinson's, a stuffy nose, sinus cancer.
If you haven't already figured it out, Jennifer Traig is a hypochondriac, a condition that afflicts anywhere from 1 to 5 percent of Americans.
Jennifer Traig's new memoir about her hypochondria and the history of the condition is called ""Well Enough Alone."" We'll speak with her this hour and as always, we'd like to hear from you.
Do you think you might be a hypochondriac and why?
Have you been accused of being one only to discover you actually really were sick?
Give us a call.
Our number is 800-989-8255.
The email address is talk@npr.org, and you can also share your experiences with us on our blog, that's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Later in the program, making robots cute and cuddly.
Why so many people fell for a trash compactor with big eyes.
But first, Jennifer Traig and the cultural history of hypochondria.
She joins us now from member station KQED in San Francisco.
Jennifer, welcome to the show.
Thanks for having me.
And now, when you were in the second grade, your Halloween assignment at school was to draw the scariest thing you ever saw.
Can you tell us the story?
Yeah.
I, of course - well, my friends and classmates were, you know, drawing werewolves and vampires.
I drew an aneurysm.
(Soundbite of laughter)
An aneurysm.
A brain aneurysm.
Yeah.
It is, in fact, what had killed my grandfather and was this absolutely the scariest thing I could think of and drew a picture of a vein exploding, which is how I understood it.
My mother, understandably, not amused, was quite horrified and sent me to my room, as I recall.
You were what, eight years old at the time?
Yeah, seven.
So have you been a hypochondriac most of your life?
Yeah, you know, I dabble.
I have a lot of anxiety disorders and hypochondria, you know, in the rotation along with OCD and panic and anxiety and, you know, the grab bag of neurosis.
But ever since I was about four I remember thinking there were things wrong with my body.
Now, hypochondria is something mocked and lampooned.
It's not really, sort of, taken seriously, but you write that it is, at least from your perspective, something that is increasingly being taken seriously by the medical establishment.
Why is that?
Well, there's a big financial incentive to do so.
Hypochondria costs, it's estimated, about 20 million dollars a year in unnecessary tests and procedures.
So it makes a lot of financial sense to figure out that someone's a hypochondriac and not, you know, actually a cancer or a cardiac disease patient.

So I think HMOs are very invested in trying to root them out early and get them into treatment that really helps and really works, and part of that's removing the stigma and weeding out people who are truly sick from people who are truly sick with hypochondria.
So this is a real condition, this is a condition that has been, sort of, described by psychologists, psychiatrists and others and studied.
Yeah, it is.
It's very old.
It dates back to the fourth century BCE.
The term was first coined by Hypocrites, and at that point it was just an anatomical term.
It was hypo, underneath the condrium, which was your rib cage, and it - as time went on it began to be associated with more symptoms.
By the second century, Galen had identified it and was describing it as a condition with various vague complaints.
And it was taken very seriously.
The popularity waned somewhat during the Middle Ages but by the end of the Renaissance there was full-blown hypochondriac chic, and the only thing I can liken it to...
Hypochondriac chic?
Yeah, it was the strange to imagine now, but it was a very popular disease.
It was a disease of the wealthy and the educated.
It was taken very seriously.
It was not - and today, you know, thanks to Woody Allen, and I truly mean thanks to Woody Allen, it's a funny disease but at the time it was taken quite seriously.

It was celebrated in lots of artwork and poems, there's a famous Pindaric ode by Lady Winchelsea called ""The Spleen,"" and Mollier wrote ""The Imaginary Invalid."" He actually died shortly after playing the title role when he hemorrhaged on stage.
There's a famous painting of Marat bathing.
Right, right.
I wanted to ask you a serious question because some of your - obviously, a lot of your memoir is humorous and painful.
But explain something to me.
You write that hypochondriacs think they're sick, and in your case it was the same because they really feel sick, you actually feel pain, you have symptoms.
So where does it come from?
How does that happen?
Right, and that's something I didn't know until I started doing the research for the book.
I knew I was a hypochondriac and I was embarrassed by that.
When I started doing the reading I came to understand that, you know, I think I'm sick because I really do have symptoms.
Hypochondriacs have this amazing talent for translating stress and anxiety into actual physical symptoms that you can't fake.
It's just that there's no underlying pathology.
You don't have cancer but you truly do have a skull-crushing headache, your hair truly is falling out, your arm really is swollen, you do have mysterious bruising and rashes.
It's just that there's no underlying disease besides the hypochondria.
It's not killing you, you just think it is.
